dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: US productivity growth has been lagging behind the eurozone for two decades now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: U S productivity growth has been lagging behind the eurozone for two decades now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and since the pandemic, it's actually dropped by more than 6% in the US—that's a huge gap compared to Europe's surge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and since the pandemic, it's actually dropped by more than six percent in the U S-that's a huge gap compared to Europe's surge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period more than adequate performance by Americas own historical standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Some people are pointing to the lack of fiscal stimulus here, but that doesn't really explain why productivity specifically is suffering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Some people are pointing to the lack of fiscal stimulus here, but that doesn't really explain why productivity specifically is suffering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and like, you'd think with loose labor markets, companies would be hiring more productive workers, but it seems like the opposite is happening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and like, you'd think with loose labor markets, companies would be hiring more productive workers, but it seems like the opposite is happening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—firms are actually replacing capital with labor, so they're not investing in things like automation or ATMs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-firms are actually replacing capital with labor, so they're not investing in things like automation or ATMs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because when I was in Paris last year, even fancy restaurants had QR code ordering, but here it feels like we're stuck in another era.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because when I was in Paris last year, even fancy restaurants had Q R code ordering, but here it feels like we're stuck in another era.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code. Patrons of Parisian bistros horrified by this thought may argue that a Franco-American cultural difference is at work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then again, this isn't just a recent thing—US productivity was already slower than Europe's before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't tight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then again, this isn't just a recent thing-U S productivity was already slower than Europe's before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't tight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So maybe it's not just about stimulus or employment levels. What about technology adoption? The article mentions American firms have been slower to capitalize on digital tools.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So maybe it's not just about stimulus or employment levels. What about technology adoption? The article mentions American firms have been slower to capitalize on digital tools.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, while American firms have been quicker to capitalize on digital technologies, the timing is wrong here, too: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And now with AI, we're kind of in that trial-and-error phase—the so-called productivity J-curve, where things might get worse before they get better.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now with A I, we're kind of in that trial-and-error phase-the so-called productivity J-curve, where things might get worse before they get better.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The inevitability of errors means that productivity is likely to fall before rising, a phenomenon economists call the productivity J-curve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Europe's strong unions might actually be encouraging tech adoption, oddly enough, because they want job security through efficiency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Europe's strong unions might actually be encouraging tech adoption, oddly enough, because they want job security through efficiency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or maybe it's just luck—like, Europe got a boost from not being as vulnerable to energy disruptions thanks to, uh, Putin's policies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or maybe it's just luck-like, Europe got a boost from not being as vulnerable to energy disruptions thanks to, uh, Putin's policies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree. European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Mario Draghi—he's supposed to propose ways to boost EU productivity later this year, but the article sarcastically says he won't recommend anything groundbreaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Mario Draghi-he's supposed to propose ways to boost E U productivity later this year, but the article sarcastically says he won't recommend anything groundbreaking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Observers like me can confidently predict what Draghi will recommend because such proposals have been around for years. Europe should move now to implement these old ideas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's almost like Europe doesn't need to reinvent the wheel—they're doing fine without drastic changes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's almost like Europe doesn't need to reinvent the wheel-they're doing fine without drastic changes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Something seems to be going seriously right in the US and seriously wrong in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So for the US, it might be about catching up on tech and reevaluating how we approach labor and investment, rather than just pumping more money into the economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So for the U S, it might be about catching up on tech and reevaluating how we approach labor and investment, rather than just pumping more money into the economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely gives you a lot to think about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely gives you a lot to think about.

artist_script:
On a quiet Tuesday afternoon, in a studio overlooking the city skyline...
HostA: US productivity growth has been lagging behind the eurozone for two decades now.
HostB: Yeah, and since the pandemic, it’s actually dropped by more than 6% in the US—that’s a huge gap compared to Europe’s surge.
HostA: Some people are pointing to the lack of fiscal stimulus here, but that doesn’t really explain why productivity specifically is suffering.
HostB: Right, and like, you’d think with loose labor markets, companies would be hiring more productive workers, but it seems like the opposite is happening.
HostA: Exactly—firms are actually replacing capital with labor, so they’re not investing in things like automation or ATMs.
HostB: Which is wild, because when I was in Paris last year, even fancy restaurants had QR code ordering, but here it feels like we’re stuck in another era.
HostA: But then again, this isn’t just a recent thing—US productivity was already slower than Europe’s before the pandemic, when labor markets weren’t tight.
HostB: So maybe it’s not just about stimulus or employment levels. What about technology adoption? The article mentions American firms have been slower to capitalize on digital tools.
HostA: And now with AI, we’re kind of in that trial-and-error phase—the so-called productivity J-curve, where things might get worse before they get better.
HostB: Meanwhile, Europe’s strong unions might actually be encouraging tech adoption, oddly enough, because they want job security through efficiency.
HostA: Or maybe it’s just luck—like, Europe got a boost from not being as vulnerable to energy disruptions thanks to, uh, Putin’s policies.
HostB: And then there’s Mario Draghi—he’s supposed to propose ways to boost EU productivity later this year, but the article sarcastically says he won’t recommend anything groundbreaking.
HostA: Yeah, it’s almost like Europe doesn’t need to reinvent the wheel—they’re doing fine without drastic changes.
HostB: So for the US, it might be about catching up on tech and reevaluating how we approach labor and investment, rather than just pumping more money into the economy.
HostA: Definitely gives you a lot to think about.
